overview_of_class: This course will focus on the art of politics and the politics of the literary imagination in Revolutionary America as a means of rethinking traditional accounts of both the literature and politics of the American Revolution. Radically utopian in its desire and vision, the American Revolution was also driven by feelings of loss, betrayal, anger, and fear, and haunted by the specter of ghosts, insurrection, and apocalypse. We will explore the affective, sensational, and specifically literary shaping of various founding documents as a means of illuminating some of the more visionary, terroristic, and contradictory aspects of the American Revolution; and we will consider the ways the imaginative writings of the time?poems, letters, autobiographies, novels of seduction, the gothic, and the terrors of Islam?reveal aspects of the "real" American Revolution that were repressed, silenced, or written out of the more official writings of the Revolution.

descriptions.value: Thomas Paine, Common Sense; Thomas Jefferson, Declaration of Independence and selections from Notes on the State of Virginia; Letters of Abigail and John Adams; Benjamin Franklin, Autobiography; Phillis Wheatley, Poems; Hector St. John de Crèvecoeur, Letters from an American Farmer; Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, John Jay, The Federalist Papers; Hannah Foster, The Coquette; or, the History of Eliza Wharton; Charles Brockden Brown, Edgar Huntly; or, Memoirs of a Sleep-Walker; Royal Tyler, The Algerine Captive.

overview_of_class: The deathbed confession. The religious confession. The false confession. The confessional Facebook post. This seminar will explore how the numerous forms of confession illuminate the role of personal narratives, autobiography, and the first-person "I" in nineteenth- and twentieth-century American literature as well as our current cultural moment. We will begin by examining sensation fiction, crime journalism, and confessional poetry by authors such as Mark Twain, Edgar Allan Poe, and Sylvia Plath. We will then apply our literary paradigms and methods of analysis to other media forms like television series, movies, blogs, tumblrs, and podcasts. In doing so, we will consider the social, political, and cultural power of the confession in the present day, as well as its connection to important social and ethical issues such as individual and collective responsibility, criminal justice and punishment, and mental health and illness.

descriptions.value: One in-class presentation, one mid-term essay, one final essay, and weekly Canvas posts on present-day confessional narratives.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Short stories by Mark Twain, Edgar Allan Poe, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Jack London, and others; selected poetry by Robert Lowell, Anne Sexton, and Sylvia Plath; theoretical texts by Paul de Mann, J. L. Austin, and Peter Brooks; and confessional blogs, tumblr sites, and podcasts.

Texts will be available at: Norris campus bookstore; course reader available at Quartet Copies.
